subject: Economics
title: IKEA Effect: Love What You Build
description: A short lesson to help you apply IKEA Effect: Love What You Build.

hook.text: People who assemble IKEA furniture value it 63% more than identical pre-assembled furniture. Effort creates love.

buildup.text: Dan Ariely tested this: people who built origami valued their ugly creations almost as highly as expert origami.

discovery.text: When we invest labor, we invest identity. The thing we made becomes an extension of ourselves ‚Äî and therefore precious.

twist.text: Betty Crocker cake mixes originally required just adding water. Sales were poor.

climax.text: The IKEA effect explains why DIY, cooking, and crafting feel rewarding. The labor is the product, not just the result.

punchline.text: We don't love things because they're valuable.

quiz.question: What does the IKEA effect demonstrate?
options: People place higher value on things they helped create or assemble
Cheap products feel expensive after assembly
